author: nycdesigner

description.text:
EDIT 7/30/16:I just updated the tolerances as my first version was WAY off (sorry about that). But i have increased the depth of thread from 2mm to a little over 3mm and tested one in ABS which finally worked actually. haha. So i plan to do furthur testing and prints within a day or so to nail this out. Thanks for being patient! EDIT 8/1/16:I also just changed the CAD file to print default with the flat side to the bottom as it was upside down by default. EDIT 8/2/16:Today i think i finally finished nailing this out. I printed a finalized test piece in ABS after realizing i had the helix backwards which caused counterclockwise threads, and obviously those did not work. But the latest test piece works! I plan to make one out nylon and iglide I180-PF filaments soon. I now consider this done and not a "work in progress". enjoy! This is a MTS Flange Mount Supernut, a Delrin style Lead Nut, LeadScrew Nut, Trapezoidal, Triangular, etc. This is designed to be a plastic replacement for the Lulzbot Mini, but any 3D printer with a 10mm Leadscrew w/ a 2mm pitch should work. Soft "self lubricating" plastics with a low coefficient of friction such as Nylon would probably work best, but others have said that other plastics such as PLA may work fine. Or one might try the new igus Tribo-filamnt:
http://www.igus.com/wpck/11723/N14_4_1_iglidur_TriboFilament?C=US&L=en Also, a special thanks to JEZZMUND for uploaded a modified version of his design to mirror my design with triangualar mounting holes. His design is shorter and has OpenScad threads. I personally think my threads are smoother than the OpenSCAD ones on his model. He claims that PLA seems to work well. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:138504

author: gheide

description.text:
The Nexus 4 wireless charging orb has a design problem, after a while the phone just slides right off as dust builds up in the rubber ring.  
There are two other docks out there on Thingiverse to solve this problem but I found them to be too bulky for my tastes, so I made this very minimal design to solve my problem.  
And yes, I got cheeky with the name ;)

Printed in ABS without support, the arms got a little rough because one layer wasn't cooling enough before the next layer was added, so if I were to print it again I'd probably add some support during the slice, or find some way of making the printer pause for 10 secs between layers when it's up to the arms.  
I've included the source SketchUp file, please feel free to modify it and come up with your own twist on the design!

title: Switch Knob Part 1 of 2 for Floor Lamp - Outer Cap

description.text: This design is for a floor lamp that has a switch on the floor lamp's shaft. Some floor lamp switches can break due to a thin flange that can break over time that is on the inside of the lamp switch (that part is replaced by Switch Knob Part 2 of 2 for Floor Lamp - also available here on Thingiverse).

You should print this with 1.5 mm filament. 
Print both parts for this project (1 of 2 and 2 of 2).
Unscrew the nut that retains the lamp's on/off switch. Put part 2 of 2 into the plastic lamp on/off switch. Replace the nut on the lamp â€“ this holds on part 2 of 2. Place part 1 of 2 onto part 2 of 2. 
Tolerances should allow for both parts to have a tight fit. However some sanding or reaming may be needed to get the parts to fit together.
The Switch Knob Part 1 of 2 for Floor Lamp part may have to be epoxied to Switch Knob Part 2 of 2 for Floor Lamp. Use plumbers two part epoxy putty if the space between both parts is too great after sanding. Five minute epoxy dried overnight should glue part 1 of 2 and 2 of 2 together well.

description.text: UPDATE V3: I tweaked the design a bit again, making it a bit smaller to fit in the game box easier and so my printer could print two at a time. I also made the holes more symmetrical. UPDATE: I added a new version which makes the base a bit thinner so it doesn't take quite as long to print. It also includes a gap in the bottom which makes them stackable. Lastly, I made the 11th meeple slot (The one for our house rule) a little thinner. It was a little wide so the meeple would lay at a slant and now it will stand like the rest. I left the original because when you print the thinner version, you can see through the holes a bit if you print in a light color. It doesn't effect anything, really, and you can't tell when it's sitting on the table, but it is a factor. I designed this to be used as a sort of score tracker for the board game Lift Off. The goal is to rescue your team of aliens before the planet explodes. The only thing I didn't like was that there was nowhere fun to put them after they escaped the planet, but there is now! There are spaces for all ten alieneeples and a space in back for Garglore, because he needs to be rescued, too! (We have a house rule for how to rescue the misunderstood monster.) I printed this on my New Matter MOD-t with no supports and it turned out great. Enjoy! I remixed this from lilykill's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231923

description.text:
Three color Oregon Beavers logo coaster. I printed this with ABS using .3mm layer height with a total of 17 layers. Layers 1 thru 9 were printed with white, next I switched to black for layers 10 and 11, then finally to orange for 12 thru 17.
I have single extruder printers, so I have it lift and pause for 30 seconds while I change filament color.
The biggest problem is that the friend I printed it for liked it and wants a set of 12!
I need a two head machine. Or a better filament splicer so I could measure and splice it and not have change during printing.

Easy to produce. It doesn't require an insanely calibrated printer and lacks the need of cage-requirements due to use of cylinders instead of round balls. The bearing really works well with this design.
I used it as a part for a horizontal filament spindle feeder.

The cylinders go into the base and the top should be glued to finish the bearing. Use the little hole to align the inner-top. Needles to say, there should not be any glue other than a tiny bit on the center of the inner-top and the edges of the outer-ring top, to keep everything in place.

author: suzy7023

title: Raspberry Pi 2 or B+ Case With Fan

description.text:
I was using the case design by Normand and really like it.  However, I was noticing the temp on the Pi was up in the 40C range.  I looked around for another case with a fan, but didn't find one.  So I took Normand's design and added a 40mm fan.  It dropped the temp from the 40C range down to the upper 20's.
The fan gets its power from the GPIO connector and because of this, I removed the knockout for it.  I created a small opening over the pins were the power is located because there was no space between the case and the pins for the power connector.  I relocated the slot for the camera cable to make room for the fan.  I only modified the top case from the original design.  I am including the unmodified bottom for completeness.
I included a fan cover that provides a blade guard and hides the power connector and wires.  It is designed for a 40mm x 40mm x 10mm fan. I used M3 x 18mm bolts for mounting the fan and cover.  There are also 4 M3 nuts embedded on the underside of the cover.
If you don't mind the connectors and wires being visible, you don't need to use the cover.

title: Super Joe

description.text: This is a 3D full body scan of me, Joe Grand, in a muscle-busting, super hero pose. The scan was done by CyberFX in Burbank, CA during the filming of Prototype This' Robotic Firefighter Assistant episode, in which we were tasked with creating a high-tech, body-forming firefighter pack.

This was one of the first prints I tried on my Thing-o-Matic w/ Plastruder MK5. I printed with support material and raft turned on, which made me look like Han Solo in Carbonite. After a bit of clean-up, it was barely good enough for my two-year-old :)

Traditional folk instruments, conventionally made by the musicians themselves, are now being mass produced and readily available for purchase by anyone who wants one. These days, the way they are made is a complete mystery to lay folk, and a clear line has been drawn in the sand between those who create them and those who play them. People are taking another look at the maker culture, which has been around for a while, and redesigning items as new contemporary tools.
Here we are proposing a brand new instrument (a digital folk instrument) that is created using a 3D printer and is an extension of existing folk instruments such as the Asalato and the Patika. This entry showcases artistic expression with a workshop event where participants learn to make digital folk instruments, learn to play them, and then they go on to learn to play them accompanying a DJ.
https://vimeo.com/148963935
I publish how to make digital folk instrument on the web !
http://fabble.cc/tomohiroinoue/xxxxxxxxx
Please try to make it　!!

remixed_from.title: Tube Collar Locks Dust Filter Plate

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Extruder Shroud with PTFE Connection

description.text: This is an updated version of my Extruder Shroud with the addition of a PTFE connection. The PTFE connection was initially designed by user coberdas in his design called “Tube Collar Locks Dust Filter Plate”…. With coberdas permission I extracted one of the nozzles from his design and included it in my updated shroud. To be very clear, I have not printed this updated piece yet but I figured I would put it out there since it’s a pretty cool design and there is nothing as far as I know like this for the i3. If someone does print out this version before me and finds any alignment issues please let me know and I will tweak the design. Thank you Please refer to user coberdas design for fitment tweaks as it pertains to the cap and locks. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:324946

author: chuckb258

description.text:
This is a remix of the Arctic Cat Snowmobile Choke Lever. Changes that I made include: 1) Add threads to the tube and nut using Poor man's openscad screw library.
2) Increase the size of the base and width of the shaft on the cable puller.
3) Increase the width of the lever to match the puller.
4) Add the text "Choke" to the lever.
5) Create an over sized nut with "Arctic Cat" text https://youtu.be/VU-hWi7gOz0

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High .1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Supports are only needed for the lever Print the cable puller and main tube at the same time. It can be difficult printing a single cable puller by itself as layers don't have a chance to cool enough and stacking hot plastic results in a melty pile of goo.
I used a cotter pin instead of zip tie to connect the lever to the puller

Notes: Both Nut and back Bolt are not threaded, but press fitted because of the small size. Both are printed with the flat side down (as shown in the pictures). I put a thin solid layer in the Nut between the two different sized holes so support material will not be need. The thin layer acts like a bridge to allow the smaller hole to be printed on top of the bridge. This bridge can be removed after printing. I have included the 123D files so it can be modified for your zipper size.

This printed for me very tight and took some detailed clean up for the two peaces so they fit together.  I used an Exacto knife to clean up any artifacts on the Nut and Bolt.  Remove the bridge in the center of the nut.  The bolt is pressed into the zipper hole and the nut pressed on the front of the zipper.  If the fit is loose, it can be glued together.

description.text: This is a toolbox that can hold chocolate balls or lollies.  Makes a nice presentation box.

To make, you need to print: 1x Base
2x Drawer
4x Choc Insert
4x Long Rod
8x Short Rod
2x Lid
2x Handle
28x Snap-plugs
  • Put 2 choc holders in base.
  • Load a choc holder into each drawer.
  • Attach rods to ends drawers and hold in place with snap-plugs.
  • Attach rods drawers to base with snap-plugs in the rods.
  • Attach lid using snap-plugs.
  • Pop in handles into lids.

18/12/2015: Added Washer part - because I ran out of M3 washers. I'm thinking it may be possible to make a snap-in part rather than use screws and nuts. Some testing required.
19/12/2015: Updated Choc Insert so it can be printed more easily - bottom of hemispheres held together before they're joined.
20/12/2015: Added Snap-plugs. This removes need for any hardware (was using M3 nuts, washers and bolts). Model is now completely 3D printable.
21/12/2015: Test print is complete. The snap-in plugs seem to work OK. Two things: The lid opens a bit when it is being carried by the handles, and the rods are probably a bit thin. So I'll need to work on that - but otherwise it's OK. I might also get to making some other inserts to use but for the moment it holds Lindt chocolate balls.

title: X-Wing Game Base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A base for the ships in the Star Wars X-Wing miniatures game.  I picked up a copy today that was missing all of the bases.  I tried printing out a couple of the designs already posted to Thingiverse but I couldn't get them to fit the components correctly.  Tolerances are tough sometimes.  So I broke out the calipers on my good copy of the game and made my own model.
I put holes into the base so that the design uses less material.  I also avoided replicating those teeny tiny directional keys on the original's rod, instead I designed some larger, more difficult to break connections.  This means that the ship's connector slides inside of the base rod, but it seems a small compromise to have a much sturdier result.
I've found a bit of variability even in PLA I've printed with, some spools seem to come out a bit tighter than others.  So your mileage may vary, but this design works well for me.  Enjoy!
Update - added a revised version.  This new version has the post narrowed by a tiny bit to ease assembly, and I've added bevels to the post hole, the supports that sit against the back of the ship identifier tokens, and to the sides of the base.

title: Switch Knob Part 2 of 2 for Floor Lamp - Inner Shaft

description.text: This design is for a floor lamp that has a switch on the floor lamp's shaft. Some floor lamp mechanical switches can break due to a thin flange on their inner shaft that can break over time (this thin flange is held on the inside of the lamp switch's retaining nut). This flange is what keeps the lamp's on/off switch attached to the lamp. Switch Knob Part 2 of 2 for Floor Lamp replaces the part that has a broken flange. Use this part with "Switch Knob Part 1 of 2" for Floor Lamp - this part is also available on Thingiverse. "Switch Knob Part 1 of 2 for Floor Lamp" is the cap for this part.

You should print this with 1.5 mm filament. 
Print both parts for this project (1 of 2 and 2 of 2).
Unscrew the nut that retains the lamp's on/off switch. Put part 2 of 2 into the plastic lamp on/off switch. Replace the nut on the lamp â€“ this holds on part 2 of 2. Place part 1 of 2 onto part 2 of 2. 
Tolerances should allow for both parts to have a tight fit. However some sanding or reaming may be needed to get the parts to fit together.
The Switch Knob Part 1 of 2 for Floor Lamp part may have to be epoxied to Switch Knob Part 2 of 2 for Floor Lamp. Use plumbers two part epoxy putty if the space between both parts is too great after sanding. Five minute epoxy dried overnight should glue part 1 of 2 and 2 of 2 together well.

The details are small in the part 2 of 2 switch knob part and using a filament that is finer may equal a better end product.

description.text:
A smaller and portable bartop, take it to your friends house and connect it to a tv... Have fun... Video
https://youtu.be/AqWY2wX-Cr8

This is a 3D printed adapter used to take photos through a microscope. Several similar models are available on the internet but I found them to be designed either for a specific mobile phone or, when adaptable, to be very clunky, large or complicated. 
This design makes provision for most phones, the width can be anything from about 55mm 90mm and the length is not really a limited since it is open at the top and bottom. I would estimate that the maximum thickness is about 12mm. The print is designed to handle off center cameras as well (in case you camera is centered to the other side you might have to flip the print which can be easily done on most printers.)
This design only have 3 printed parts, 5 screws and 5 nuts (nuts are optional in most cases since the screws holes are designed to be tight enough to get away without the nuts) Only one clamp stl is supplied, flip the "CLAMP" stl to print the second clamp.
An M3 screw is needed for the clamp around the microscope lens. Four M4 screws are needed for the 2 clamps to clamp the mobile.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Two clamps are needed, the one should be mirrored.
The design places the camera off center. Depending on the position of the camera lens on the mobile you might have to mirror the eye mount print as well. Only drill out the holes if you want to use nuts, otherwise screw directly into the plastic. If you think that that is not secure enough, add nuts where necessary.

title: Tripod mount for HS-422 servo motor

description.text:
I wanted a pan/tilt head for my webcam, and I already had two servos with a pan/tilt bracket, and a raspberry pi/miscellaneous junk to control them. My pan/tilt bracket doesn't support the bottom servo, so it's not stable without a better base. I figured attaching it to a photography tripod would work well, so this model was born.
I tried using the OpenSCAD thread library to build the threads into the bracket. After the first print didn't fit the bolt, and the next few scaled prints weren't quite right, I decided to just use a metal nut. This seems like a better design anyway.

author: monguin

description.text:
My apartment building keyfob was too big for my liking, so I made a new one, about as small as it can be. I'm not sure about the model or type of the tag, but it's about the same diameter as a US penny (19mm), and less than half as thick (<1mm).
I borrowed the general design from a different (commercially produced) keyfob. I needed to be able to insert the RFID tag, so it's open on one side, and the keyring keeps it inside. Its a pretty snug fit anyway, you need a pin or something to get it out.

title: QAV250 32mm board camera piitch gimbal mount

description.text: This was specifically designed for the Lumenier CS-600 board camera mounted on the QAV250. It should fit other 32mm board cameras but may need to be trimmed or adjusted slightly to fit. Here is the original design if you want to try and make a copy of the design and edit it to fit a different board cam: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fqlsTjqRy8e-lumenier-board-cam-gimbal-v8/edit. The entire assembly was made to mount snugly between the 2nd set of standoffs. The front servo mount is intentionally tall because it "sandwiches" the mount between the upper and lower frame plates. This allows the mount to stay locked in place without any screws or other hardware to mount it to the QAV250 frame. The screws that mount the camera mount to the gimbal base are #2x7/16" servo screws. I believe that the screws to mount the board to the camera mount are the ones that came with the plastic case that Lumenier sells: http://www.getfpv.com/ultra-light-plastic-lumenier-camera-case.html. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rMJGkurOnY

comments.author: jbs

description.text:
Outside dimensions were referenced from a schematic from Martin Taylor. Chamfers and fillets were added in areas to strengthen design. Lightsaber is hollow and will house electronics and lights when I am done with it. I included the fusion 360 achieve file and a .step file so that you can edit it if you wish. Total parts to print: 5-7 (Depending if you print the tube mount and the battery lock) Build size
Largest part is a little less than 5in tall. Which will fit on most printers I know and work with. Some threads can be removed to reduce that size. Supports
There are duplicates of the parts that require supports. You can choose to use the supports I generated with Meshmixer or you can take the files without the Supported prefix and add your own supports. Blade
For my lightsaber I am using a 5ft x 1in OD tube. The nylon tube I am using doesn’t thread easily and is thin so there is a tube attachment with threads on it. Print it and force it onto the bottom of the tube. Light sanding of the tube may be required. I found a good link for tube in this pdf:
http://www.hyperdynelabs.com/docs/hyperblade/HyperBlade%20saber%20blade%20kit.pdf
They recommend two different tubes. One for the inside led blade and another for the outside blade.
Outside tube: http://www.mcmaster.com/#8628k67/=10fuu6s
My current design only accounts for the outside tube. A small change to the Tube Attachment can allow for both tubes.
They sell it in 5ft length. I cut mine down to around 3ft (according to some forum posts about blade length). Battery
The RidgedHandle component is designed with the intention of housing a 18650 rechargable battery (~67mm x 18.8mm OD). There is enough room on the sides of the battery to run wires past it. USB
Ordered from Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00R3B0AOK?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=od_aui_detailpages00
Mounts into bottom section. With threaded cap to protect if from dust when not using.
The bottom also uses left-handed threads, so that you can undo the usb cap without unscrewing the entire lightsaber.

Notes: Supports
There are duplicates of the parts that require supports. You can choose to use the supports I generated with Meshmixer or you can take the files without the Supported prefix and add your own supports.

Thread cleaning After printing this on a Makerbot with PLA, I ran sand paper and a sharp deburring tool in areas that need it. Threads fit perfectly. Love the feel of it. Optional painting Using silver and gold sharpie paint pen. The Silver turned out really nice. I need to hone the gold into a copper-rustic look. Will update with pictures if I change it.

Schematic from Martin Taylor. Referenced dimensions to create outer body. Design to Cardboard cut-out from 123D Make to 3D printing. Designed in Fusion 360. Easy to use and free software for education and hobbyists/ enthusiasts. Cross Section of lightsaber. 18650 battery is the yellowish block nested into the RidgedHandle. I also have the bright LED I am using at the top.

title: Knob for Fan Speed Control  - Lasko Oscillating

description.text: This design is for some models of Lasko fans that have broken fan speed control knobs. The replacement knob design is stronger than the original knob that comes with some Lasko fans. If you have a broken speed control knob on a fan, this stl file/print might do the trick - and you can put away those pliers!
You can print out using 3mm or 1.5 mm filament. Tolerances should allow for a snug fit. If the fit is a little too tight, ream out with a round file/half round file or small diameter drill.

title: Eurorack 3D Printed Knob
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Originally designed for the attendees of the monthly DIY ModSynth workshop in Perth West Australia (WAMod). It pressure fits over multiple different types of pot, toothed or smooth shaft, with tight tolerances.
You will need to experiment with your pots and printer.
Ive noticed that the tolerances are so tight that by printing in white, for example, prints a knob that is too big for a pot that is perfectly OK with the same .stl file printing in black... Go figure.
One of best things about this design is that it has a raised pointer on its top so the pot can easily be turned with just one finger. Really important when you cant get both your finger AND thumb through the mess of patch cables. Handy. The x49 .stl file has 49 knobs packed together that prints successfully on my 3DUP Mini in 4-10 hours depending on resolution. Again this design is a result of many hours of tweaking and refinement, it is offered for you to use for free, please be kind and remember its not for resale or redistribution.

title: Two Color Dice - for single nozzle

description.text:
1.Print the inner and measure it, then edit the model and print again. You'll need a cube at real size 9.45mm^3.
2.Change another color.
3.Print outter. Pause the printer at the first layer over 11mm.
4.Put the inner inside of the outter.
5.Resume and finish the print. Add these into the Gcode at the right layer:
G1 X0.0 Y0.0 ← Move the extruder to 0,0
M25 ← Pause the print

This print was created to protect wires going through a 55mm hole in sheet metal. It can be also used for holes that are deep. If the metal sheet is thinner than 2mm, you should scale the part by 1.05.
There is a groove on the back face, so that any residue from cutting the metal would not affect how the print sits on the sheet. 
Second there are four grips that are design to hold the part in place. They move about one millimeter when 5nm force is applied. Stress of the movement is applied to a large area, not just at the bottom of the grip, to prevent the grip from snapping off.

comments.text: Can someone else who has this setup contact me and help me troubleshoot mine?  I cant get rep g to see 2 extruders but when I go into the control panel it see's the heated build platform is attached to the other extruder but wont show a temp for it.  Also my temp readout is wonky...
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: Sounds like you need to set the tool index on the second extruder controller to 1.  I had trouble doing this and had to temporarily switch to version 2.8.  Basically, you want just the second ec plugged into the cat5, then in repg goto set tool index to 1, then you can plug them both in and upgrade to version 3 and you should see both correctly.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: I upgraded them both to version 3 using repg 25 (or was it 26 the one that came out yesterday) So I just need to set my tool index then?
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Well I think version 3 has a bug that doesn't let you set the tool index, that's why I had to temporarily downgrade to 2.8
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: oh ok thanks I'll try that.  Any you think that will rectify both issues? The non connection of the toolhead and the wonky temperature readings?
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: I think both problems are caused by not having the toolhead indexes right.  Before I got the second ec set to toolhead 1, I was getting random temperature fluctuations too.  It went away when I got the indexes straight.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: Yeah the problems with  temperature fluctuations and the second extruder controller not being seen both went away.  My abp build platform is reading 120 degrees all the time with no change though.  (could be because of no actual abp it does heat up so...)  I also cannot get my left extruder to heat up...  Did you have to make an estop frankencable to hook both estops up to the same motherboard too?  I'm a bit worried mine didn't come out right (the lights on the safety relay gives the all clear though)
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: If you're seeing the ABP hot when it's not, make sure it is attached to whichever extruder you dubbed Index 1, and that the cables are all plugged in (way to many times was it my cables, not software). The default wiring assumes that you set the original ToM extruder controller's index to 1 before adding the second controller, so in machines.xml that's how I defined it. handy trick: if you hold down the reset button on one of the controllers and send the "set index" command, it will set the index of the other controller. No need to unplug everything! The same goes for sending toolhead preferences, actually.

  • It better drives the belt.
  • It already has 2 bearings included
  • No need for plastic washers anymore.
  • It's more robust and won't break compared to the plastic case for a standard bearing
  • it's more expansive than the solution using a standard 625ZZ bearing and a plastic cage
  • it reduces vibrations
  • It increases belt lifespan
  • It reduced ghost effect on printed parts
  • it increases overall print quality

title: X Axis Belt Tensioner for Wanhao i3, Monoprice Maker Select, Cocoon Create etc.

description.text: For easier installation and tightening of the X-Axis belt on a Wanhao Duplicator i3. Requires a M3x30 (or longer; 40mm is recommended) screw and a M3 nylock nut. Update 04/07/2016: Uploaded corrected bearing block for Igus bushings. Uploaded a bearing block option with Igus integrated. Renamed and reorganized the files. Came up with clever name "X-Tension." The files now available are: X-Tension_Bolt_On_To_Stock_Bearing_Block.stl - For use with the stock aluminum blocks, or with individually printed bearing blocks. If used with the stock aluminum blocks, you will need to tap threads into the blocks. The 3D printed bearing blocks by tahustvedt have threaded holes all the way through. Download the bearing blocks at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1172838. If this option causes the bottom of the belt to not run parallel with the top of the belt, you may need amkza's remix at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1535626. X-Tension_With_Bearing_Block_for_Stock_Bearing.stl - If you're printing the bearing blocks anyway, I recommend printing this one with the belt tensioner integrated. It has even thicker walls for added strength, and the belt grips are a little lower for better alignment with the motor and pulley. This file uses tahustvedt's "tight bearing hole" block for use with linear ball bearings such as the stock LM8UU bearings, or longer LM8LUU bearings. X-Tension_With_Bearing_Block_for_Igus_Bushing.stl - Same as above, but this file uses tahustvedt's "oversized bearing hole" version for use with the Igus Drylin bushing, model number RJ4JP-01-08. X-Tension_With_Bearing_Block_with_Igus_Combination.stl - This version of the tensioner with bearing block uses 3DDOC's bearing block with the Igus bushing built in. X-Tension_Clip_01.stl - The original clip design. This requires the belt to be cut shorter, but it looks a lot cleaner. X-Tension_Clip_02.stl - New clip design based on JonBAL's clip idea. The belt can be looped around the clip meaning it does not have to be cut shorter. The excess can be rolled up and zip tied out of the way. I enhanced JonBAL's clip by making the part of the clip the belt wraps around thicker for additional strength.

History Update 12/25/2015: Belt grips moved 2mm lower for better alignment. Update 12/26/2015: Added a version with the belt tensioner integrated with tahustvedt's bearing block as one piece. Update 01/23/2016: Updated newer versions with slightly thicker walls for additional strength. Update 04/05/2016: Added bearing block compatible with Igus Drylin bushings. Based on vxxs's work at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1206622. This remix was created to aid easier printing with fewer supports needed. You should be able to print any of the above parts with no supports.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

comments.author: Heathicus

comments.text: I am printing the Tensioner_On_Bearing_Block_With_Clip.stl now -- almost done.  Couple questions.  Do I need to buy any screws for this?  Just asking because it's integrated onto the bearing block.
comments.author: Heathicus

comments.text: You will need a M3x30 (or longer) screw and a M3 nylock nut.  And this design does require cutting the belt shorter.  I understand, I was pretty nervous about doing that too!  Just make sure that you have all the parts you need, they're strong and solid with good layer adhesion, everything fits together well, before you cut the belt.  And if the worst happens and you need to return everything to stock, be prepared to be down until you can get a replacement belt.  That's the nature of making modifications like this!

title: 3D printed F450 type quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is another printable quadcopter (F450 type). Some parts are remake of existing ones with personal mods/improvements and some others are own design. It flies really well, having less weight and flex than original DJI F450! All parts shown on 3D drawings are printable parts (including cases!) and has been optimized for an easy and effective FDM printing. ... i will still adding/updating files to this thing as i design new mods/options/improvements, so stay tuned. Print settings:
-Print on .STL position without supports (i use .25mm layer height). Print only parts you need (ie you want legs?, you want GPS?). Legs types:
Legs are optional but recommended parts because they damp hard landings
There are different types:
The short legs are designed for using when nothing is installed under the bottom plate, the medium legs can be used when the battery is installed under bottom plate and the large ones when you install a large load under the bottom plate like a gimbal. Print one part of each but:
-Arms: You need x4.
-Legs: You need x2 of typeA and x2 of typeB.
-APM2 damp: You need x2 pieces of dampBottom. I use next infills with really good compromise between weight and strength:
-Arms: PLA 30% infill. I use M3 inserts of about 4mm OD and 4mm height pressed as threads (see pics and video).
-Legs: PLA 100% infill.
-Rest of parts: PLA 20% infill. -For assembling use a bunch of M3x5mm and M3x8mm bolts and some M3 washers. -My build weight without battery (including APM and basic FPV video gear) is only 815 grams. -The camera i used is the microCamera with audio from here http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-700TVL-2_8mm-Lens-170-Degree-Wide-Angle-FPV-Camera-5-12V-p-992610.html -The GPS case is designed for fitting this GPS http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:358329 UPDATES:
Jan/02/2017: Added SolidWorks sources. Share your mods!
Oct/01/2016: Added Inserts pressing video
Feb/06/2016: Added GPS case and microCamera mount.
Feb/04/2016: Update bottom plate with 45mm mounting holes for PDB.
Jan/02/2016: Added different legs types and packet into a .zip file.
Jan/02/2016: GPS parts packet into a .zip file. For leave only main parts on the thing page.
Dec/21/2015: Added APM2 damper and APM2 3D printed case (Zip file).
Dec/21/2015: Replaced legsLarge by V3.
Dec/18/2015: Added damping legs "legsLarge".
Dec/18/2015: Replaced arms by v2. Iron inserts pressing:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNevkIJiUmI Enjoy having a cool 3D printed quadcopter!

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs. You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com Thank you!

A friend had a pomegranate deseeder and asked if I could design one for 3D printing.  Voila!  My dad suggested making two versions, the shorter one taking a few less hours to print, but still fully functional.  
If you haven't used one before, you will be amazed at how quickly you can get the seeds out of a pomegranate. There are videos online on how to use it, but basically you cut the pomegranate in half at the equator, make 4 or 5 scores into the outside of the fruit, place the deseeder over a bowl or plate, and then bang on it with a spoon.  It flattens the pomegranate and the seeds fall into the bowl.
The scorer works well for cutting into the pomegranate.  It also works well on oranges.  There are two versions of the scorers, the second version including six scorers.
